results.title: My life to study
results.creator_credit: Fei Hu Song, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: When Fei Hu Song and his family came from China to Australia, they all took English language courses. This began for Hu Song a lifetime of study and of making Australia his home.

results.title: Harry Bachelor
results.brief_description: Harry Bachelor loves his city, loves his life…until, a lone parking meter with canabalistic tendencies inhabits his street. While Harry tries to cope, the trying meter swells in greed and size to become a larger than life sparring partner. Will Harry fight this all the way to City Hall? or will Harry snap under the strain adopting uncharacteristic behaviour?
results.description: Harry Bachelor loves his city, loves his life…until, a lone parking meter with canabalistic tendencies inhabits his street. results.title: RMIT AIM Collection 1992
results.brief_description:
Compilation of student work from the University of RMIT Animation and Interactive Media (AIM) Department. 1992.
The Centre for Animation and Interactive Media, its courses, facilities, staff and collection of work was transferred from Swinburne University of Technology to RMIT University in 1995.

results.title: Sisters are doin' it for themselves: women in the contemporary music industry
results.creator_credit: Greg Ferguson, Lindy Morrrison, AUSMUSIC and Conspiracy Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Basic music industry skills”.
Module 4.5. Pursuing a career in the rock music industry is not easy for women and the path to success is often difficult. Lindy Morrison, an ex-band member of the groups The Go-Betweens and Cleopatra Wong, interviews women who have worked in artistic and non-artistic roles in the industry. In terms of gender balance, radio airplay, income and participant numbers, there is still room for improvement. Key female industy figures featured include Kylie Minogue, Wendy Matthews and Tina Arena, along with ‘pioneer’ artists such as Judy Stone, Laurel Lee and Little Pattie.
results.title_for_label: Sisters are doin’ it for themselves: women in the contemporary music industry
results.creator_credit_for_label: Greg Ferguson, Lindy Morrrison, AUSMUSIC and Conspiracy Films

In terms of gender balance, radio airplay, income and participant numbers, there is still room for improvement. results.title: Songlines: contemporary aboriginal music
results.creator_credit: Richard Frankland, John Foss, Australian Contemporary Music Development Co (AUSMUSIC) and Golden Seahorse Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Basic music industry skills”.
Introduction to the Music Industry. Module 4.6. Contemporary Australian Aboriginal music has become an international presence in recent years. This program profiles artists who have taken their brand of indigenous music to the world: Yothu Yindi, Archie Roach and Tiddas. Traditional elements are incorporated into contemporary styles. This is not simply a matter of throwing in the odd didjeridu and clap stick, but rather the traditional cultural role of Aboriginal music as an educational medium is maintained and extended to cover new, important issues and themes.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Richard Frankland, John Foss, Australian Contemporary Music Development Co (AUSMUSIC) and Golden Seahorse Productions

This is not simply a matter of throwing in the odd didjeridu and clap stick, but rather the traditional cultural role of Aboriginal music as an educational medium is maintained and extended to cover new, important issues and themes.

results.title: Waiting to laugh
results.creator_credit: Hamid Naemi, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Now settled in Australia, Afghani born Hamid reflects on the difficult and lonely times he and his sister experienced when they moved to Iran after their mother’s unexpected disappearance and their father’s death one year later.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Hamid Naemi, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: The Ties that bind
results.creator_credit: Milad Bardan, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: It took seven years after the death of his mother and a political assassination in his birth country of Lebanon before Milad really got to know his father. This is a tribute to that man.
